Task.title: Task
Task.description: Represents a task in the TaskFlow application.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Task entity.

description.description: A detailed description of the task.

dueDate.description: The date and time when the task is due.

category.description: The category of the task (e.g., work, home).

isCompleted.description: Indicates whether the task has been completed.

reminderTime.description: The date and time when a reminder should be sent for the task.

User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the TaskFlow application.

id.description: Unique identifier for the User entity.

theme.description: The user's preferred theme (e.g., light, dark).

definition.description: Stores user profiles. Access is restricted to the user themselves.

params.name: userId

definition.description: Stores tasks owned by a specific user. Access is restricted to the user who owns the task.

params.name: userId
params.description: The unique identifier of the user.

params.description: The unique identifier of the task.

firestore.reasoning: The Firestore structure is designed to ensure Authorization Independence, DBAC, and QAPs. It leverages path-based ownership for user data and tasks. Specifically, tasks are stored within user-specific subcollections (`/users/{userId}/tasks/{taskId}`), enforcing clear ownership and simplifying security rules.  The `userId` on the task document is redundant given path-based ownership, but simplifies queries (though queries are discouraged for ownership checks as rules are not filters).  This eliminates the need for complex `get()` calls in security rules. Data segregation is achieved by storing user-specific data in separate collections. This structure supports secure `list` operations, as rules can easily verify the `userId` against `request.auth.uid`.
